title: State v. McCluney
description: This is a cocaine-trafficking case.  The State presented evidence that Respondent attempted and conspired to purchase cocaine, so the Court of Appeals erred by holding that Respondent was entitled to a directed verdict.  Reversed and Remanded.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Petitioner,
v.
Larry Dean McCluney, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF 
  APPEALS

Appeal From Cherokee County
Â J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25909
Heard November 17, 2004 - Filed December 
  6, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy
Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy
Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney
General David Spencer, all of Columbia, and Harold W.
Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Petitioner.
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ACTING JUSTICE MYERS: Â This is a cocaine-trafficking case.Â  Larry Dean 
  McCluney (Respondent) was convicted of trafficking in more than 400 grams of 
  cocaine in violation of South Carolina Code section 44-53-370(e)(2)(e). [1] Â  The circuit court sentenced Respondent to 
  twenty-five years of imprisonment and a fine of $200,000.Â  The Court of Appeals 
  reversed, holding the circuit court should have granted Respondentâ€™s motion 
  for a directed verdict.Â  State v. McCluney, 357 S.C. 560, 593 S.E.2d 
  509 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of 
  Appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Respondent was charged under section 44-53-370(e)(2)(e) with trafficking in 
  more than 400 grams of cocaine.
At trial the State presented evidence that Respondent agreed with two other 
  persons to purchase over 400 grams of cocaine from a fourth person, who happened 
  to be a police informant.Â  The State also presented evidence that in a reverse-buy 
  operation conducted by police with the help of the informant, Respondent and 
  the other two persons purchased over 400 grams of imitation cocaine, thinking 
  it was real.
ISSUE
Whether Respondent was entitled to 
  a directed verdict.
ANALYSIS
A defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to present 
  evidence of the offense charged.Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 
  544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).
The Court of Appeals held that Respondent was entitled to a directed verdict 
  because a transaction involving imitation cocaine â€œdoes not fall under the purview 
  of the trafficking statute.â€Â  State v. McCluney, 357 S.C. 560, 565, 593 
  S.E.2d 509, 511 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  According to the court, â€œthe only indictable 
  offense applicable to imitation cocaine would be under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-390(a)(6) 
  (2002).â€ [2] Â  McCluney, 
  357 S.C. at 564, 593 S.E.2d at 511.Â  We disagree.Â  
Trafficking is not limited to the substantive offenses of purchasing, 
  possessing, and selling large amounts of controlled substances.Â  Conspiring 
  and attempting to do those acts also constitute trafficking.Â  The part of the 
  trafficking statute pertinent to this case is as follows: â€œAny person who knowingly 
  â€¦ attempts[] or conspires to â€¦ purchase â€¦ ten grams or more of cocaine â€¦ is 
  guilty of a felony which is known as â€˜trafficking in cocaine.â€™â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 44-53-370(e)(2) (2002).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The Court of Appeals errantly focused on the facts that only imitation cocaine 
  was present at the transaction and that purchasing imitation cocaine does not 
  constitute trafficking.Â  In doing so, the court relied heavily on Murdock 
  v. State of South Carolina, 311 S.C. 16, 426 S.E.2d 740 (1992), which is 
  irrelevant to Respondentâ€™s case.Â  
The court should have focused on the Stateâ€™s evidence that Respondent conspired 
  and attempted to purchase real cocaine.Â  Section 44-53-370(e)(2) plainly states 
  that conspiring and attempting to purchase ten grams or more of real cocaine 
  constitute trafficking.Â  The presence of only imitation cocaine at the transaction 
  is irrelevant to Respondentâ€™s intent and thus irrelevant to the Stateâ€™s conspiracy 
  and attempt arguments.Â  Respondent was not entitled to a directed verdict.
CONCLUSION
The State introduced evidence that Respondent knowingly agreed with at least 
  one other person to purchase real cocaine and took a substantial step toward 
  fulfilling his intention.Â  Because conspiring and attempting to purchase ten 
  grams or more of real cocaine constitute trafficking, the Court of Appeals erred 
  by holding that Respondent was entitled to a directed verdict.Â  Due to this 
  error, the Court of Appeals declined to address the other two issues before 
  it.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals and the case are respectivelyÂ  

REVERSED AND REMANDED.        
  TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(e)(2)(e) (2002).

 
   [2]  â€œIt is unlawful for a person knowingly or intentionally 
    to â€¦ distribute or deliver a noncontrolled substance or an imitation controlled 
    substanceâ€ that is represented as or appears to be a controlled substance.Â  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-390(a)(6) (2002).

title: Sutton v. State
description: In this post-conviction relief (PCR) action, Petitioner argued the PCR judge erred in dismissing his application as untimely because neither trial nor appellate counsel informed him of the availability of PCR following his conviction and unsuccessful appeal.  The Supreme Court affirmed the dismissal of the application, concluding neither trial nor appellate counsel has a duty to inform a convicted defendant of the availability of PCR or the one-year deadline to file an application.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court



  
    
      
Johnny Wayne Sutton, Petitioner,
v.
State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lancaster County
Paul E. Short, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25910
Submitted October 20, 2004 - Filed December 
  13, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Phillip J. Mace, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, 
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney 
  General Elizabeth R. McMahon, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  The circuit court dismissed Johnny W. Suttonâ€™s 
  (Petitioner) post-conviction relief (PCR) application as barred by the statute 
  of limitations.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Petitioner was convicted in 1991 of murder and was sentenced 
  to life in prison.Â  We affirmed.Â  State v. Sutton, Op. No. 93-MO-197 
  (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed July 19, 1993) (unpublished decision).
Petitioner filed his first PCR application on May 8, 2001, 
  and later amended it.Â  He alleged the one-year statute of limitations should 
  not bar his application because his trial and appellate attorneys failed to 
  inform him of his right to seek collateral review of his conviction on grounds 
  not available in a direct appeal.
The PCR judge dismissed Petitionerâ€™s application as untimely 
  without an evidentiary hearing because it was filed nearly five years after 
  July 1, 1996 - the deadline to file an application for all persons convicted 
  before the effective date of the statute of limitations contained in S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A) (2003).Â  See Peloquin v. State, 321 S.C. 468, 
  469 S.E.2d 606 (1996).
We granted Petitionerâ€™s writ of certiorari to address a 
  novel issue:

Did the circuit court err in summarily dismissing Petitionerâ€™s 
  PCR application as untimely, where Petitioner alleged he did not file a timely 
  application because neither his trial nor his appellate attorneys informed him 
  of the statutory right to file an application?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Dismissal of a PCR application without a hearing is appropriate 
  only when (1) it is apparent on the face of the application that there is no 
  need for a hearing to develop any facts and (2) the applicant is not entitled 
  to relief.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-70(b) and (c) (2003).Â  When considering the 
  Stateâ€™s motion for dismissal of an application, where no evidentiary hearing 
  has been held, the circuit court must assume facts presented by an applicant 
  are true and view those facts in the light most favorable to the applicant.Â  
  Similarly, when reviewing the propriety of a dismissal, we must view the facts 
  in the same fashion.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-80 (2003) (PCR 
  actions are governed by usual rules of civil procedure); Wilson v. State, 
  348 S.C. 215, 559 S.E.2d 581 (2002); Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 
  364, 527 S.E.2d 742, 747 (2000).
In a case raising a novel issue of law, the appellate court 
  is free to decide the question of law with no particular deference to the trial 
  court.Â  Osprey, Inc. v. Cabana Ltd. Partn., 340 S.C. 367, 372, 532 S.E.2d 
  269, 272 (2000); Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 
  411, 526 S.E.2d 716, 718 (2000).Â  We will reverse the PCR judgeâ€™s decision when 
  it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 
  651, 594 S.E.2d 462, 465 (2004); Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 145, 
  526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000). 
LAW AND ANALYSIS
Petitioner argues the PCR judge erred in dismissing his 
  application as untimely because neither trial nor appellate counsel informed 
  him of the availability of PCR following his conviction and unsuccessful appeal.Â  
  We disagree.
A person convicted or sentenced for a crime has a statutory 
  right to file a PCR application.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 17-27-10 to -160 (2003).Â  
  In a PCR proceeding, â€œthe focus usually is upon alleged errors made by trial 
  or plea counsel. . . . The applicant attempts to show that his or her attorney 
  erred in a manner that a reasonably proficient attorney would not, and that 
  the error prejudiced his case.â€Â  Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 363-364, 
  572 S.E.2d 742, 747 (2000) (explaining the history and basic principles of the 
  PCR process, and holding that PCR generally is limited to collateral attacks 
  on the validity of a conviction or sentence). 
A PCR action is a civil action generally subject to rules 
  and statutes that apply in civil proceedings.Â  Wade v. State, 348 S.C. 
  255, 263, 559 S.E.2d 843, 846-847 (2002); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-80 (2003).Â  
  A PCR application ordinarily â€œmust be filed within one year after the entry 
  of a judgment of conviction or within one year after the sending of the remittitur 
  to the lower court from an appeal or the filing of the final decision upon an 
  appeal, whichever is later.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-27-45(A) (2003).Â  After the 
  Legislature enacted the statute of limitations in 1995, we held that all persons 
  convicted before the statuteâ€™s effective date had one additional year to file 
  an application.Â  Consequently, the application of persons such as Petitioner 
  had to be filed by July 1, 1996.Â  Peloquin v. State, 321 S.C. 468, 469 
  S.E.2d 606 (1996).
Absent extraordinary circumstances, such as when a defendant 
  inquires about an appeal, there is no constitutional requirement that a defendant 
  be informed of the right to a direct appeal from a guilty plea.Â  Weathers 
  v. State, 319 S.C. 59, 459 S.E.2d 838 (1995).Â  On the other hand, when a 
  defendant is convicted and sentenced after a trial, â€œtrial counsel in all cases 
  has a duty to make certain that the client is fully aware of the right to appeal, 
  and if the client is indigent, assist the client in filing an appeal.â€Â  Wilson 
  v. State, 348 S.C. 215, 218 n.3, 559 S.E.2d 581, 583 n.3 (2002) (citing 
  In re Anonymous Member of the Bar, 303 S.C. 306, 400 S.E.2d 483 (1991) 
  and Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738, 87 S.Ct. 1396, 18 L.Ed.2d 493 
  (1967)); see also Rule 602(e), SCACR (â€œTrial counsel, whether retained, 
  appointed, or Public Defender, shall continue representation of an accused until 
  final judgment, including any proceeding on direct appealâ€ unless relieved by 
  court order or case is properly transferred to the state Office of Appellate 
  Defense).
We accept as true, as we must at this stage of the proceeding, 
  Petitionerâ€™s allegation that his trial and appellate attorneys never informed 
  him of the right to file a PCR application.Â  However, we decline to impose a 
  duty on trial or appellate counsel to inform a convicted defendant of the availability 
  of PCR or the one-year deadline to file an application.
We have described a PCR action as a hybrid form of action 
  because it is rooted in a criminal case, which means important constitutional 
  protections and criminal law concepts are regularly implicated.Â  Wade, 
  348 S.C. at 263, 559 S.E.2d at 847 (PCR cases are treated differently from traditional 
  civil cases, requiring, for example, that appellate counsel brief all arguable 
  issues despite counselâ€™s belief the appeal is frivolous and requiring, by statute, 
  court-appointed counsel for an indigent applicant who is granted a hearing).Â  
  Nevertheless, we reject Petitionerâ€™s argument because, while a PCR action is 
  hybrid in nature, it generally remains subject to rules and statutes that apply 
  in civil proceedings.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the PCR judgeâ€™s decision to dismiss 
  Petitionerâ€™s application because it is apparent on the face of the application 
  there is no need for a hearing to develop any facts and Petitioner is not entitled 
  to relief.
CONCLUSION
We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s dismissal of Petitionerâ€™s 
  PCR application on the ground it was barred by the statute of limitations.Â  
  We conclude neither trial nor appellate counsel has a duty to inform a convicted 
  defendant of the availability of PCR or the one-year deadline to file an application.
 AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: SCDOT v. Hinson Family Holdings
description: In this Horry County condemnation action, the circuit court granted Respondents' motion for partial summary judgment. The circuit court ruled that certain property owned by Respondents near the intersection of S.C. Highway 22 (Conway Bypass) and S.C. Highway 31 (Carolina Bays Parkway) was not landlocked due to a previous condemnation, and a public road bordering the property had not been abandoned in the manner outlined by statute.  The Supreme Court affirmed the grant of partial summary judgment to Respondents, holding the circuit court correctly concluded the old public road remains publicly accessible because no formal action has been instituted to abandon it under the statutory process.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Transportation, Appellant,
v.
Hinson Family Holdings, LLC (formerly Hinson Family Limited Partnership, 
        a South Carolina limited partnership) and Hinson Properties, LLC, a South 
        Carolina limited liability company, Respondents.
      
    
  

Appeal From Horry County
Â John L. Breeden, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25911
Heard October 5, 2004 - Filed December 
  13, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Clifford O. Koon, Paul D. de Holczer, and Mary Frances Gibson, all of Moses 
  Koon & Brackett, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Howell V. Bellamy, Jr., and Robert S. Shelton, both of Bellamy, Rutenberg, 
  Copeland, Epps, Graveley & Bowers, P.A., of Myrtle Beach, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This is an appeal in a condemnation
case which has yet to be tried.Â  The South Carolina Department of Transportation 
  (DOT) appeals a circuit court order granting partial summary judgment to Respondents 
  (Hinson).Â  This appeal was transferred from the Court of Appeals pursuant to 
  Rule 204, SCACR.Â  We affirm. 
FACTUAL ANDÂ  PROCEDURALÂ  BACKGROUND
In February 1994, DOT exercised its right of eminent domain 
  and filed a notice of condemnation and lis pendens to purchase 102 acres in 
  Horry County from International Paper Realty Corp. (International Paper) for 
  construction of new S.C. Highway 22, the Conway Bypass.Â Â  The project included 
  the new highway and relocation of a portion of the public Watertower Road, a 
  logging road that had been maintained by the county and used by the public for 
  years.
In March 1994, International Paper sold 160 acres to Apache 
  Group II, an entity owned by Hinson.Â  Apache Group II had notice of the anticipated 
  condemnation proceeding involving Highway 22 and relocation of Watertower Road 
  from the condemnation and lis pendens notices filed with the clerk of court 
  and a pre-sale survey of the property.Â  Apache Group II subsequently conveyed 
  the property to Hinson in 1999. [1] 
  
In June 1994, DOT and International Paper settled the condemnation 
  action.Â  The settlement was based on a 1993 appraisal and included payment for 
  a 25 percent diminution in the value of adjoining property owned by International 
  Paper.Â  The appraiser reduced the value of the adjoining property because Highway 
  22 (running north-south) would divide it, and access to the new highway and 
  the relocated Watertower Road would be reduced. 
A second appraiser hired by DOT in 1993 valued the acreage taken 
  and the impact on remaining parcels, but did not specify any diminution in value 
  due to a loss in right of access to public roads from the property at issue 
  in the present case.Â  In fact, the second appraiser stated no â€œuneconomic remnantâ€ 
  would exist after construction of Highway 22 and, although various parcels would 
  be divided, â€œthe remaining portions can be accessed from relocated [Watertower 
  Road].â€Â  The acreage purchased by Hinson included the adjoining property for 
  which DOT had compensated International Paper for diminished value because of 
  reduced access to public roads.
In September 2000, DOT began condemnation proceedings to purchase 
  approximately 88 acres of Hinsonâ€™s property for construction of new S.C. Highway 
  31 (running east-west), the Carolina Bays Parkway, and an interchange with Highway 
  22.Â  DOT informed appraiser John Wilkins that it had fully compensated the previous 
  property owner (International Paper) in 1994 for loss of the right of access 
  to public roads as a result of the condemnation action related to the construction 
  of Highway 22.Â  DOT took the position that Hinson had purchased the acreage 
  from International Paper knowing it was without access to public roads.
Hinsonâ€™s property lies on both sides of Highway 22:Â  an 
  eastern portion of 132 acres and a western portion of 28 acres.Â  The highest 
  and best use of the non-wetland acreage was as residential resort property, 
  which appraiser Wilkins valued at $13,000 per acre.Â  Hinsonâ€™s property is located 
  near Barefoot Resort, a mixed-use residential community north of the Intracoastal 
  Waterway and east of Highway 22.Â  The appraiser, accepting DOTâ€™s assertions, 
  concluded the eastern portion of the property was landlocked before the taking 
  and valued non-wetland portions of it at $1,300 per acre - a ninety percent 
  reduction from the market value for non-landlocked property.Â  
Hinson moved for partial summary judgment on the issue of 
  whether the eastern portion of the property was landlocked.Â  Hinson argued (1) 
  DOT neither paid it nor International Paper for loss of all right of access 
  to public roads, indicating DOT did not believe or try to assert the property 
  was landlocked until realizing that position might allow it to pay less for 
  Hinsonâ€™s property in the 2000 condemnation action; and (2) the eastern portion 
  was not landlocked when Hinson purchased it in 1994 or as of September 2000 
  because it bordered old Watertower Road which, while no longer maintained by 
  the county, had not been formally abandoned and was still publicly accessible.Â  
  Hinson relied in its arguments on the 1993 appraisals and affidavits and correspondence 
  from county, International Paper, and DOT officials involved in the previous 
  condemnation action.
In response, DOT presented similar affidavits from five DOT officials 
  or subcontractors who set forth the history of events related to the 1994 transactions 
  and construction of Highway 22.Â  The affiants stated Hinson had knowingly purchased 
  a parcel of property landlocked by Highway 22 and the relocation of Watertower 
  Road.Â  The affiants and DOT further asserted that, as of September 2000, Hinsonâ€™s 
  acreage was landlocked because the parcel did not include a strip of land 100 
  feet wide that lies between the north end of the eastern portion of Hinsonâ€™s 
  land and the relocated Watertower Road.Â  International Paper retained that strip 
  of land in the 1994 transaction, but subsequently sold it to another entity.Â  
  The appraiser also relied on the fact Hinson did not own the 100-foot strip 
  in concluding the eastern portion was landlocked.
DOT contended that even if Hinson had access to old Watertower 
  Road in 1994, Hinson did not have access when DOT filed notice of the condemnation 
  action in September 2000 because the old road was closed and abandoned in late 
  1999 when the relocated road was opened.Â  DOT argued there was a factual dispute 
  on whether the eastern portion was landlocked, making summary judgment inappropriate.
The circuit court granted Hinsonâ€™s motion for partial summary 
  judgment, concluding Hinsonâ€™s property was not made completely inaccessible 
  by the 1993 condemnation action.Â  Although DOT compensated International Paper 
  for a 25 percent diminution in value due to reduced access, old Watertower Road 
  never had been abandoned under the statutory process and so remained publicly 
  accessible.Â Â  â€œ[I]t is clear to the Court the subject parcel enjoyed some access 
  [to public roads] on the date the Highway 31 Condemnation Notice was filedâ€ 
  in September 2000, the circuit court stated.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court may properly grant a motion for summary judgment when 
  â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, 
  together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as 
  to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as 
  a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 
  S.C. 318, 487 S.E.2d 187 (1997).Â  In determining whether any triable issues 
  of fact exist, the court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences 
  that may be drawn from the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving 
  party.Â  Manning v. Quinn, 294 S.C. 383, 365 S.E.2d 24 (1988).Â  On appeal 
  from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all 
  ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in 
  a light most favorable to the appellant, the non-moving party below.Â  Williams 
  v. Chesterfield Lumber Co., 267 S.C. 607, 230 S.E.2d 447 (1976).
ISSUE

Did the circuit court err in granting Hinsonâ€™s motion for 
  partial summary judgment because a genuine factual dispute exists on whether 
  old Watertower Road has been formally abandoned?Â  

LAW AND ANALYSIS
DOT contends the circuit court erred because this case presents a 
  genuine issue of material fact:Â  whether Horry County abandoned the portion 
  of old Watertower Road which abutted Hinsonâ€™s property when the road was relocated 
  in late 1999 during construction of Highway 22.Â  We disagree. 
  [2] 
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-9-10 provides, â€œany interested person, the State 
  or any of its political subdivisions or agencies may petition a court of competent 
  jurisdiction to abandon or close any street, road or highway whether opened 
  or not.â€Â  Notice must be given to the public by newspaper advertisements and 
  to abutting landowners by mail.Â  Section 57-9-10. Â The court must determine 
  if it is in the best interest of all concerned to abandon or close the street, 
  and determine in whom the title to property comprising the former street shall 
  be vested.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-9-20 (1991).
â€œBy creating a formal judicial procedure for terminating 
  a public right of way over land, [Section 57-9-10] removes the uncertainty attending 
  the common law of dedication and abandonment.Â  It also ameliorates the rigor 
  of the common law rule requiring strict proof of intent to abandon a public 
  right of way before that right can be extinguished.â€Â  Hoogenboom v. City 
  of Beaufort, 315 S.C. 306, 319, 433 S.E.2d 875, 884 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  DOT 
  and the local municipality are indispensable parties that must be joined in 
  an action to abandon a public road.Â  Without their inclusion, they would not 
  be bound by the decision or discharged from their maintenance duties or other 
  obligations and liabilities.Â  BancOhio Natl. Bank v. Neville, 310 S.C. 
  323, 426 S.E.2d 773 (1993).
Watertower Road is an admittedly public road, although the 
  record does not reveal whether it became public by dedication or through prescriptive 
  or long-established use.Â  It is undisputed that no interested person has instituted 
  an action under the statutory process to effect an abandonment of old Watertower 
  Road.Â  Moreover, an affidavit and letter from an Horry County official show 
  the county had ceased maintaining, but had not abandoned, the portion of old 
  Watertower Road abutting Hinsonâ€™s property.Â  In light of these facts, conclusory 
  assertions by DOTâ€™s affiants regarding the allegedly landlocked nature of Hinsonâ€™s 
  property are insufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact.Â  The circuit 
  court correctly concluded old Watertower Road remains publicly accessible because 
  no formal action has been instituted to abandon it pursuant to Sections 57-9-10 
  and -20.Â  
CONCLUSION
We affirm the circuit courtâ€™s ruling old Watertower Road 
  remains publicly accessible.Â  Accordingly, as a matter of law, Hinsonâ€™s property 
  was not landlocked as a result of the 1994 condemnation action or the relocation 
  of Watertower Road in 1999.Â  We remand this case for further proceedings consistent 
  with this opinion.
We decline to address the additional sustaining ground 
  raised by Respondents regarding the propriety of an implied, appurtenant easement 
  by necessity.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 
  311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining 
  issue when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
AFFIRMED.  Â Â Â Â 
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Â  
    The parties apparently agree this transfer has no impact on the analysis of 
    this case because Apache Group II, Hinson Family Holdings, the former Hinson 
    Family Limited Partnership, and Hinson Properties, LLC, are all owned and 
    controlled by Keith Hinson.Â  We will refer only to Hinson in this opinion 
    for purposes of clarity.Â Â Â  

 
   [2] Â  
    DOT in its brief argues the circuit court should have applied S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§ 57-5-80 (Supp. 2003), which addresses the removal of highways from the state 
    highway secondary system of roads.Â  This argument was withdrawn at oral argument 
    because counsel for DOT acknowledged havingÂ  mistakenly believed Watertower 
    Road was part of the stateâ€™s secondary system.

description: This is a judicial discipline opinion imposing a public reprimand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        In the Matter of Charleston Municipal Court Judge Arthur C. McFarland, 
          Respondent. 
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25912
  Submitted November 30, 2004 - Filed December 20, 2004

PUBLIC REPRIMAND

 
   
     
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for The 
          Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Coming B. Gibbs, Jr., of Charleston, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this judicial disciplinary matter, respondent and the 
  Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline 
  by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent 
  admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a public reprimand pursuant 
  to Rule 7(b), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement and impose a public 
  reprimand.Â  The facts as set forth in the agreement are as follows.Â  
FACTS
While serving as a part-time municipal judge for the City of Charleston, respondent 
  also engaged in the practice of law.Â  In his legal capacity, respondent undertook 
  to represent a client, accepted a fee, and filed a lawsuit on the clientâ€™s behalf.Â  
  After further investigation, respondent concluded the clientâ€™s claim lacked 
  merit, but failed to advise the client and never sought to dismiss the lawsuit.Â  
  Respondent failed to advise the client of receipt of a summary judgment motion 
  and failed to respond to the motion.Â  Without consulting the client, respondent 
  failed to comply with discovery requests and failed to comply with two federal 
  court orders directing respondent to comply with the discovery requests.Â  Moreover, 
  although he met with the client approximately seven times after the summary 
  judgment motion had been granted, respondent never told his client his case 
  had been dismissed.Â  Finally, respondent failed to timely return the clientâ€™s 
  file after the client terminated representation and requested the fileâ€™s return.Â  

 The client filed a complaint with the Commission on Lawyer Conduct.Â  ODC requested 
  respondent respond to the complaint.Â  Respondent failed to respond; ODC sent 
  a â€œTreacyâ€ letter in which ODC pointed out that respondentâ€™s failure to respond 
  to the complaint would constitute lawyer misconduct.Â  See In the Matter 
  of Treacy, 277 S.C. 514, 290 S.E.2d 240 (1982).Â  Respondent failed to respond 
  to the second request from ODC.
ODC then served respondent with a Notice of Full Investigation.Â  See 
  Rule 19, RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  Respondent failed to respond to the Notice 
  of Full Investigation.Â  ODC then had the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division 
  serve a subpoena on respondent directing that he appear at a specific time and 
  place for an on-the-record and under oath interview and to bring documents with 
  him for inspection.Â  Respondent failed to appear as directed, but did contact 
  ODC and reschedule the interview.Â  Respondent subsequently appeared for the 
  rescheduled interview and provided ODC with the subpoenaed documents.Â Â  
As a result of the above misconduct, respondent was publicly reprimanded in 
  his capacity as a lawyer.Â  In the Matter of McFarland, 301 S.C. 101, 
  600 S.E.2d 537 (2004).Â  This reprimand constituted the fourth time respondent 
  had been disciplined for professional misconduct as a lawyer.Â  
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent has violated the following Canons of the Code 
  of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold integrity 
  of the judiciary); Canon 1A (judge should participate in establishing, maintaining, 
  and enforcing high standards of conduct, and shall personally observe those 
  standards so that the integrity of the judiciary will be preserved);Canon 2 
  (judge shall avoid impropriety in all activities); Canon 2A (judge shall respect 
  and comply with the law and shall act at all times in a manner that promotes 
  public confidence in the integrity of the judiciary); and Canon 4(A)(2) (judge 
  shall conduct all extra-judicial activities so that they do not demean the judicial 
  office).Â  By violating the Code of Judicial Conduct, respondent has also violated 
  Rule 7(a)(1) of the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR 
  (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of Judicial 
  Conduct).Â  In addition, he has violated Rule 7(a)(2), RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR 
  (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to willfully fail to appear personally 
  as directed, willfully fail to comply with a subpoena, or knowingly fail to 
  respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority to include a request 
  for a response or appearance).Â Â  
CONCLUSION 
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and issue a public reprimand.Â  
  Accordingly, respondent is hereby reprimanded for his misconduct.Â  
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Murphy v. NationsBank
description: This is a Court of Appeals certiorari.  The issue on appeal is whether a party to an action is entitled to mileage and a witness fee for attending a deposition.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Loren John Murphy, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        NationsBank, N.A., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
  Â John C. Hayes, III, Special Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25913
  Heard November 4, 2004 - Filed December 20, 2004

REVERSED

 
   
     
      
        James J. Raman, of Spartanburg, for Petitioner.
        Donald E. Rothwell and Scott Louis Hood, both of Irmo, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review 
  the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Murphy v. NationsBank, N.A., 354 S.C. 
  495, 581 S.E.2d 849 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The Court of Appeals held that a party 
  to an action is not entitled to mileage and a witness fee for attending a deposition.Â  
  We reverse. 
Â FACTS
Petitioner, Murphy, filed suit against Respondent, NationsBank (Bank), alleging 
  Bank had filed a negative credit report against him.Â  During discovery, Bank 
  noticed Murphyâ€™s deposition.Â  Counsel notified Bank that Murphy expected a witness 
  fee of $25.00 plus mileage.Â  NationsBank filed a motion to enforce discovery 
  and, after a hearing, Judge Hayes ordered Murphy to appear at the deposition 
  without being paid a witness fee and/or mileage.Â  Murphy appealed to the Court 
  of Appeals which affirmed the trial courtâ€™s ruling that Murphy was not entitled 
  to the fee and mileage.
ISSUE
 
  
    Is a party to an action entitled to a witness fee and mileage for attending 
      a deposition?
  

DISCUSSION
In Perry v. Minit Saver Food Stores, 255 S.C. 42, 177 S.E.2d 4 (1970), 
  this Court answered the precise question before us.Â  There, we held the word 
  â€œwitness,â€ as used in Circuit Court Practice Rule 87, included a party such 
  that the plaintiff was entitled to a witness fee and mileage.Â  We stated, â€œ[w]e 
  are of the view that there is no ambiguity whatever in Rule 87 as to the meaning 
  of the word â€˜witnessâ€™ . . . and that the word â€˜witnessâ€™ was intended to mean 
  all witnesses whose depositions are taken pursuant to the rule, whether or not 
  the witness, perchance, be a party.Â  The word â€˜witnessâ€™ is used at various other 
  places in Rule 87 to denote all witnesses, including parties, without making 
  any distinction between witnesses who happen to be parties and those who are 
  not.â€Â  255 S.C. at 45, 177 S.E.2d at 5.
Circuit Court Rule 87 was repealed and replaced with Rule 30(a)(2), SCRCP, 
  effective July 1, 1985.Â Â  The pertinent provision of Rule 30(a)(2) provides, 
  â€œ[a] witness attending any deposition held pursuant to these rules shall receive 
  for each day's attendance and for the time necessarily occupied in going to 
  and returning from the same, $25.00 per day, and mileage for going from and 
  returning to his place of residence, in the same amounts as provided by law 
  for official travel of state officers and employees.â€ 
The Court of Appeals held that, because other sections of Rule 30(a)(2) differentiate 
  between a witness and a party, the section pertaining to payment of a witness 
  fee was just that, requiring payments only to witnesses, but not parties.Â  The 
  Court of Appeals noted that portions of Rule 30(a)(2) set forth certain limitations 
  on depositions, to wit: 

  A witness (excluding a party) may be compelled to attend only in the 
    county in which he resides or is employed or transacts his business in person, 
    or at such other convenient place as is fixed by an order of the court.Â  The 
    second paragraph states:Â  â€˜The deposition of any party or witness may 
    only be taken one time in any case except by agreement of the parties through 
    their counsel or by order of the court for good cause shown.

354 S.C. at 496-497, 581 S.E.2d 
  at 849-850 (emphasis in original).Â  Because the first paragraph of the rule 
  deals with witnesses and excludes parties, and the second paragraph deals with 
  both witnesses and parties, the Court of Appeals concluded that the third 
  paragraph, dealing with payment of witness fees, applied only to witnesses 
  and not to parties.Â  Id. at 497, 581 S.E.2d at 850.Â  This holding is 
  in direct conflict with this Courtâ€™s opinion in Perry, holding that for 
  purposes of the rule requiring payment of a witness fee, a party is a witness 
  as well as a party.Â Â  
Moreover, the Court of Appeals overlooked the fact that former Circuit Court 
  Rule 87, upon which this Court relied in Perry, contained the identical 
  provisions as Rule 30(a)(2).Â  Rule 87(A) specifically stated that â€œ[a] witness 
  (excluding a party) may be compelled to attend only in the county in which he 
  resides or is employed or transacts his business in person, or at such other 
  convenient place as is fixed by an order of the Court.â€Â  The rule went on to 
  state that, â€œ[t]he deposition of any party or witness may only be taken one 
  time in any case except by agreement of the parties through their counsel or 
  by order of the Court for good cause shown.â€Â  We nonetheless held in Perry 
  that a party witness is entitled to mileage and a witness fee.Â  Accordingly, 
  the Court of Appeals erred in holding Perry inapplicable to this case.
We hold a party to an action who is required to attend a deposition is entitled 
  to a witness fee and mileage pursuant to Rule 30(A)(2).Â  The Court of Appealsâ€™ 
  opinion is reversed.
REVERSED.
MOORE, A.C.J., PLEICONES, J., and Acting Justices Edward B. Cottingham and 
  Donna S. Strom, concur.

title: Vaughn v. State
description: In this PCR, the Court reversed and remanded the denial of relief.  The Court found trial counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument vouching for an absent witness' testimony.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        Earnest E. Vaughn, Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Anderson County
  Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25914
  Submitted October 20, 2004 - Filed December 20, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
          all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â Â  We granted the petitionerâ€™s petition to review the 
  denial of relief in this post-conviction relief (PCR) action.Â  The PCR court 
  found trial counsel was not ineffective for failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s 
  closing argument.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
At approximately 3:00 a.m. on April 10, 1997, Deputy 
  Reggie Widener (â€œOfficer Widenerâ€) was parked in a high crime area.Â  He noticedÂ  
  a car circle the area twice.Â  The petitionerâ€™s girlfriend was driving the car 
  and the petitioner was the passenger. After Officer Widener approached the patrol 
  car, the vehicle drove away at a faster rate of speed.Â Â  Officer Widener followed 
  the car which parked in the driveway of a completely dark house.Â  
After driving around the block, Officer Widener 
  saw the petitioner on the front porch with the petitionerâ€™s girlfriend in the 
  car, and he noticed the house was still dark.Â  Because there had been many complaints 
  about burglaries in the neighborhood, Officer Widener and back-up Officer Reid 
  approached the petitioner and his girlfriend and asked the petitioner for identification 
  and why he was at the house.Â  Officer Widener then asked the petitioner for 
  permission to pat him down for guns which the petitioner granted.Â  The petitioner 
  testified that he informed Officer Widener that he had several knives and a 
  marijuana joint in his pocket.Â  Officer Widener testified that the petitioner 
  did not admit to possessing any drugs prior to the search.Â  During the pat down, 
  Officer Widener testified he felt some knives.Â  While removing the knives from 
  the petitionerâ€™s pocket, Officer Widener testified he discovered a bag of marijuana. 

Officer Widener arrested the petitioner and then 
  conducted a search incident to the arrest. Officer Widener testified that during 
  this search he found an empty cigarette pack which contained thirteen small 
  bags of methamphetamines in the petitionerâ€™s coat pocket. At trial, the petitioner 
  admitted he possessed marijuana.Â Â  However, he denied ever possessing any methamphetamines.Â Â  

The petitioner was convicted of possession of marijuana and possession with 
  intent to distribute (PWID) crank and sentenced to one year and fined $1,000 
  for the possession charge and sentenced to twenty years and fined $100,000 for 
  the PWID crank charge.Â  The petitioner timely filed an application for PCR raising, 
  inter alia, the claim that his trial counsel was ineffective for 
  failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument.Â  Following a hearing, 
  the PCR court denied the petitioner relief and dismissed the petitionerâ€™s PCR 
  application.Â  The petitioner filed a motion to reconsider which the PCR judge 
  also denied.Â  
ISSUE

  Was trial counsel ineffective for failing to object to the solicitorâ€™s closing 
    argument stating what uncalled witnesses would have testified to?

DISCUSSION
Â â€œ[A] PCR applicant has the burden of proving counsel's 
  representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness and, but for 
  counsel's errors, there is a reasonable probability that the result at trial 
  would have been different. . . .Â  A reasonable probability is a probability 
  sufficient to undermine confidence in the outcome of trial."Â  Johnson 
  v. State, 325 S.C. 182, 186, 480 S.E.2dÂ  733, 735 (1997) (citing Strickland 
  v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984)).
The petitioner contends trial counsel was ineffective for failing toÂ object 
  to the solicitorâ€™s closing argument stating what uncalledÂ  witnesses would have 
  testified to and vouching for Officer Widener, the Stateâ€™s only eyewitness to 
  testify at trial.
During closing arguments, the petitionerâ€™s trial 
  counselÂ  stated:
 
  What I would like you all to remember, who else we didnâ€™t hear from that 
    was there.Â  There was another officer there, Mr. Reid.Â  Obviously he didnâ€™t 
    see anything because he is not here.
  There was a ride along in the car with Mr. Widener.Â  Sheâ€™s not here obviously 
    because she didnâ€™t see anything.Â  Eddie testified he didnâ€™t see any methamphetamines 
    out there at the trailer.Â  Ivy Roussos was out there.Â  She didnâ€™t see any.Â  
    The only person that saw any methamphetamines out there that night, April 
    10th, was Officer Widener.Â  . . . 
  They had the evidence man, the SLED guy, and I think an expert on - - one 
    of the drug agents here.Â  But nobody else.Â  They had three people at the scene 
    who testified.Â  Just Officer Widener, he [sic] the only one that saw that 
    out at the scene.Â  Thatâ€™s just one thing I want you to think about.Â  The 
    government has the burden of proof.Â  The government must prove their case.Â  
  
  And in this case, with all the other people that were there, they rely solely 
    on this one man, that one man that says he saw the drugs out there.Â  Where 
    did they come from?Â  I donâ€™t know.Â  I donâ€™t have a clue.Â  I wasnâ€™t there that 
    night.Â  I do know that there were five people there.Â  Three with the police 
    officer, with the sheriffâ€™s department, the ride along, Widener and Reid, 
    Eddie and Ivy.Â  Now, out of all those people, only one person saw drugs 
    out there.Â  I want you all to think about that. 

(emphasis added).Â  
The solicitor then gave her closing statement and stated:
 
  The defense attorney wants to know why I didnâ€™t call the other witnesses 
    to this case.Â  When I get a case I interview everybody who is involved.Â  I 
    ask them, I donâ€™t prompt them, I say what did you observe?Â  I take notes on 
    it.Â  Iâ€™m a minimalist when it comes to trying a case.Â  Your time is valuable, 
    the Judgeâ€™s time is valuable, the clerkâ€™s time is valuable, my time is valuable.Â  
    If everybody is going to say the same thing, there are no differences, then 
    Iâ€™m not going to make them come up here and testify. Thatâ€™s duplicative testimony.
  And in fact, if everybody takes the stand and says the very same thing, the 
    defense attorney can object to it.Â  We have a rule of evidence that says you 
    cannot put in duplicative testimony.Â  Now, he says if those people had seen 
    meth, they would have been here.Â  Let me put it to you this way, the defense 
    attorney has the power of subpoena.Â  He can have any single person he wants 
    to here to testify.
  I donâ€™t know if he talked to the first officer, but I do know that he subpoenaed 
    the ride along and has talked to her.Â  We called this case to trial previously, 
    and she was up here, and they discussed it with her.Â  Donâ€™t you think if she 
    was going to say, I didnâ€™t see any meth, she would have taken the stand.Â  
    He could have subpoenaed her and put her up there, but he didnâ€™t.
  The reason I didnâ€™t put them up there is because theyâ€™re going to say the 
    very same thing that my officer did.Â  .Â  .Â  . Now apparently what weâ€™re going 
    for here is that the officer planted those drugs.Â  I will be the first person 
    to admit that there are officers who will take the stand and lie.Â  That is 
    the reality of life.Â  Everyone who takes an oath does not tell the truth.Â  
    I have to my knowledge never put someone up there that would do that. . . 
    . 
  The officer had no reason to lie, and it is not necessary for me to bring 
    other people here to corroborate his testimony when theyâ€™re going to say the 
    same thing.Â  But if they werenâ€™t going to say the same thing, I would guarantee 
    you that the defense would have had them on the stand because they can subpoena 
    whoever they like. 

The State's closing arguments must be confined 
  to evidence in the record and the reasonable inferences that may be drawn from 
  the evidence. State v. Copeland, 321 S.C. 318, 324, 468 S.E.2d 620, 624 
  (1996).Â  Furthermore, a prosecutor cannot vouch for a witnessâ€™ credibility.Â  
  State v. Shuler,Â  344 S.C. 604, 630, 545 S.E.2d 805, 818 (2001).Â  A prosecutor 
  improperly vouches for a witnessâ€™ credibility and places the government's prestige 
  behind a witness by making explicit personal assurances, or indicating that 
  information not presented to the jury supports the testimony.Â  Id.
Although it would have been improper for the solicitor to vouch for Officer 
  Widener, or initiate an argument about the testimony of the absent witnesses, 
  the situation is entirely different when the defendant opens the door to the 
  subject.Â  United States v. Robinson, 485 U.S. 25 (1988)(holding solicitor's 
  closing argument that defendant "could have taken the stand and explained 
  it to you" did not violate defendant's Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination 
  because prosecutor's reference to defendant's opportunity to testify was fair 
  response to claim made by defendant in closing argument that government had 
  not allowed defendant to explain his side of story).Â  Conduct that would otherwise 
  be improper may be excused under the "invited reply" doctrine if the 
  prosecutor's conduct was an appropriate response to statements or arguments 
  made by the defense.Â  As explained in United States v. Young, 470 U.S. 
  1, 13 (1985), the idea of an invited response is used not to excuse improper 
  comments, but to determine their effect on the trial as a whole.Â Â  
Once a defendant opens the door, the relevant question in 
  determining if a defendantâ€™s rights were violated is whether the solicitor's 
  comments "so infected the trial with unfairness as to make the resulting 
  conviction a denial of due process."Â  Donnelly v. DeChristoforo, 
  416 U.S. 637, 642 (1974).Â  In Darden v. Wainwright, 477 U.S. 168, 182 
  (1986), the United States Supreme Court held that comments by a solicitor failed 
  to meet the test set out in Donnelly,Â  because 1) the comment was an 
  "invited response" to defense counsel's argument, 2) the evidence 
  against the defendant was overwhelming, and 3) the trial court instructed the 
  jury several times that its decision was to be made on the basis of evidence 
  alone and the arguments of counsel were not evidence.Â  See also 
  State v. Hawkins, 292 S.C. 418, 357 S.E.2d 10 (1987).
Here, if not for the lack of evidence, we might agree that 
  the solicitor was merely responding to the petitioner's argument. [1]  The petitionerâ€™s trial counsel argued that 
  the State had failed to call witnesses who would testify that there were no 
  methamphetamines found on the petitioner that night.Â  Thus, the petitioner "opened 
  the door" to some response from the solicitor. But See State 
  v. Engel, 592 A.2d 572 (N.J. Sup. Ct. 1991)(holding prosecutor did not express 
  personal belief as to defendant's guilt or improperly vouch for credibility 
  of police investigators when, in response to defense counsel's lengthy summation 
  characterizing State's case as a "big lie," he defended integrity 
  of investigation and prosecutor's remarks, taken in context, did not unfairly 
  prejudice defendants.)Â  Furthermore, here, the trial court instructed the jury 
  that they were to consider only the testimony that they heard at trial.
However, other than Officerâ€™s Widenerâ€™s testimony, there 
  was no other evidence that the petitioner possessed the methamphetamines. While 
  the petitionerâ€™s argument may have invited some response, the solicitorâ€™s response 
  was unfair and prejudiced the petitioner, in light of the lack of evidence of 
  his guilt on the PWID charge.Â  See State v. McFadden, 318 S.C. 
  404, 415, 458 S.E.2d 61, 68 (1995) (holding that given the ample other evidence 
  of guilt in the record, the solicitor's comments did not infect the trial with 
  unfairness to the extent that his conviction was a denial of due process).Â  

Furthermore, we note that approximately fifteen minutes 
  after beginning deliberations, the jury sent the trial judge a question.Â  The 
  jury wanted to see the â€œtestimonyâ€ ofÂ  the other officer, or more correctly 
  the dispatcher, Poulsom, who had been riding with Officer Widener.Â  However, 
  Poulsom did not testify at trial.Â  The trial judge instructed the jury that 
  they were to consider only the testimony and evidence received during the trial. 
  [2] Â  While the trial judge correctly instructed the jury to consider only 
  the evidence received during the trial, the jurors were obviously concerned 
  with the witnesses who did not testify and the arguments about them probably 
  only added to their concern.
We find the solicitorâ€™s comments prejudiced the petitioner 
  and trial counsel was ineffective for failing to object. [3]  Accordingly, the PCR court erred 
  in denying him relief.Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


 [1] The petitioner argues that the State cannot assert 
  trial strategy as aÂ  valid reason for failure to object to the solicitorâ€™s comments 
  citing Matthews v. State, 350 S.C. 272, 565 S.E.2d 766 (2002). Â While 
  at the PCR hearing, trial strategy was raised, on appeal the State does not 
  argue this as a ground to affirm.Â Â Â  
 [2]  Poulsom testified at the PCR hearing that she 
  really did not recall the arrest in any detail.
 [3] In deciding the prejudice prong in this PCR action, 
  the Court is to examine the same factors as those analyzed in deciding on direct 
  appeal whether a similar error is harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. Edmond 
  v. State, 341 S.C. 340, 348, 534 S.E.2d 682, 686 (2000).
